I have found that this only occurs on machines with two processors. My Intel 
Xeon processor has Hyperthreading, and therefore appears to Windows as if it's 
two processors. When I disable Hyperthreading so it appears as only one 
processor, I don't get these exceptions.

Since Hyperthreading is quite common in modern P4 processors, I still consider 
this Critical: the workaround is to cripple your machine.

Interestingly, my co-worker has *four* processors - that is, two physical 
processors, each with Hyperthreading enabled. She doesn't get the race 
condition / NullPointerException behavior I get. So the mere existence of 
multiple processors is not the whole story. Still, disabling Hyperthreading on 
my one physical processor definitely improved things for me.

Looking at the line numbers from the stack trace you provided, this is using 
the code before my fix went in. Please try synchronizing again, to make sure 
you have the fix. The file PIProcessListener.java should be revision 1.8.
Can you confirm whether this has been fixed (or not) in the latest code?

I got Hyades from 20040407 and re-enabled Hyperthreading. A simple profiling 
test ran correctly, with no null pointer exceptions or mysterious behavior. I'd 
say this is fixed until something new comes along.
If you come across this again, you can reopen the bug.
